text:
First things first, let me answer your questions.
My performance is mostly determined by my shots, and it's reviews. So depending on how good I can make it in the time I'm given, determines if the supervisor thinks I'm ready for bigger more difficult shots. It also shows to my colleagues what I'm capable of, which influences the social aspects of work too. On the more literal side, I have yearly performance reviews that goes into detail of what I've accomplished, my strengths, weaknesses etc.

The biggest difference between both jobs is the time I have to animate. At Framestore, since I was working for Films, I had more time to push my shots to a higher level (although that's not always the case), currently we have tighter deadline projects which means I have to be much more efficient to get good results, it's good because it forces me to simplify and focus on the basics.
Hope that answers it!

And it was really good to read your articles Nana, it give's me some more insight about your passions and why games connect with you so much :smiley:
Do you have any good animes to recommend? I haven't watched any since the first season of Attack on Titan, so it's been a while.

And last but not least your Linkedn. It's a good start Nana, I think you should definitely add your blog with your articles, and start sharing your favorite posts periodically.
It's definitely great you have a demo reel, but I think it's missing some direction and some polished work.
1. You want your demo reel to be the absolute BEST work possible - it's about quality not quantity
2. You should be looking to have a demo reel of at most 1:30mins long
3. You should specify exactly what you've done in each clip (It can be easy to mistake that you've done everything, for example the 3D models. It can be considered Plagiarism which is really serious)
4. Most demo reels are geared towards a specific job, for example a game animation reel, or a character designer portifolio etc etc.

that's the basics for now, but I did want to propose an exercise with you that will can be good  to familiarize yourself with a lot of different positions in the game industry.
If you're up for it, how about we go through the whole process of creating a Character Design to modeling, to rigging, animating and implementing in engine? What do you think?
